text: Motoko Fujishiro Huthwaite (born Motoko Fujishiro, August 24, 1927 – May 4, 2020) was an American teacher. She served during World War II, with the Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program. In 2015, she was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal. Fujishiro Huthwaite also worked closely with the Monuments Men Foundation for the Preservation of Art and its founder Robert M. Edsel to continue the mission of the MFAA and preserve their legacy. ==Life== Huthwaite was born in Boston. She graduated from Radcliffe College, the University of South Carolina, and Wayne State University. In 1941, she was sent to Japan as an exchange of nationals and was unable to get out of Japan after the outbreak of World War II. In 1945, she was recruited by Langdon Warner for the Japan division of the Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program, working under George L. Stout. She later taught at the American School in Japan. She died from COVID-19 in 2020. ==References== ==External links== * COVID-19 Claims the Life of the Last Living Monuments Woman, Monuments Men Foundation category:1927 births category:2020 deaths category:Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Michigan Category:Wayne State University alumni Category:University of South Carolina alumni Category:Radcliffe College alumni Category:American expatriates in Japan
